article_text:
The New York Mets were still on a post-season winning streak when construction-union leaders joined Gov. Andrew Cuomo to watch a game in a prime box at Citi Field, paying about $5,000 a seat for the fundraiser ticket.

Some of the same leaders were also in negotiations with top players in the city’s real estate community, trying to set more favorable terms of a state law that gives tax abatements for new developments.

In an...

twitter.description: Months of discussions haven’t produced an agreement on the developer tax break known as 421-a, and many people involved in or briefed on the discussions are increasingly prepared for no deal to be reached.
twitter.creator: @jdawsey1

image.alt: Developer tax break 421-a in limbo in New York in absence of deal on terms

twitter.title: Developer Tax Break in Limbo

article_summary:
The New York Mets were still on a post-season winning streak when construction-union leaders joined Gov.
Andrew Cuomo to watch a game in a prime box at Citi Field, paying about $5,000 a seat for the fundraiser ticket.
Some of the same leaders were also in negotiations with top players in the city’s real estate community, trying to set more favorable terms of a state law that gives tax abatements for new developments.
